Year's Ryan explaining where the book's title came from
In the late Nineteen thirties there was a British literary critic name's Sheryl Connelly and he had never really been successful himself as a writer or he desperately wanted to he knew many successful writers you'd actually gone to school at George Orwell
And so he wrote this book is a book of literary criticism and and basically it's premises how many of the books that my friends are writing that I Am trying to write that any writers publishing ... how many of them will be around in ten years
He felt like ten years was the mark of literary greatness
In the industry we recall any book that lasts for more than a year or two we called them perennial write a book that's lasted for ten years would be a very big success but
The irony is if you pull up or the New York times best seller list and you go to the the fine print at the bottom it says among the categories not actively track this time our perennial seller so there's this term
We know that these books that that last and last and yet most of our focus in the industry whether we're making books or music or movies is about new things
It was in two thousand Fifteen actually for the first time in the music business that catalog albums officially out sold new releases
And so we know that the things that were made a long time ago if you think of many of your favorite books and movies and TV shows and restaurants many of them are not brand new it's actually the ones that have really stood the test of time that we returned to over and over again
And yet it it's strange where most of the energy in these industries go and so what's so fascinating about cereals connelly's sort of journey as
He's writing about this but then can he actually do it right you know he's writing a book about creating lasting enduring work well
